instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CHGR_CSI_N: What is CHGR_CSI_N? CHGR_CSI_N is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_N and CHGR_CSI_P should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.CHGR_CSI_P: What is CHGR_CSI_P? CHGR_CSI_P is one of the current sense lines for the charger. Resistance between CHGR_CSI_P and CHGR_CSI_N should be the resistance should be the total series resistance of the current sense resistors in the circuit, usually about 20.02 ohms.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
water damage at usb <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>/100 area and near <CHIP>U9060</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.2V
PPDCIN 5.2V
L6960 0V both sides..
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.1V
dont see any short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
"L6960 0V both sides.."
You must fix this first.
If no short, post <CHIP>U6960</CHIP> voltages; 11, 10, 13.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>.
If present, change <RESISTOR>R6960</RESISTOR>.
If not, change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> 0v  on <RESISTOR>R6960</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: Just in case, before replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, check its basic voltages: <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> 0.1v
 <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 0v
VDDA/P 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHRG_AMON</SIGNAL> 5.1V
didnt find  <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> but maybe is <SIGNAL>CHRG_RST_IN</SIGNAL> 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> 0.1v"
Why changed it, if is not even powered up?

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is broken, or it doesn't get <SIGNAL>DCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at all?

"didnt find  <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> but maybe is <SIGNAL>CHRG_RST_IN</SIGNAL>"
Correct guess; but strange mention, as you already found other internal <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> signals, above mentioned.

threads.message:

<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> 5V

<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSI_N</SIGNAL> 5V

threads.message: Still <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> not present???

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 1.2V
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> =  <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> - 5.2V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at  <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>.
If still missing, change <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>; it may kill the signal because of internal failure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: change <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>? you mean <CHIP>U6960</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
Yeah, sorry; it is <CHIP>U6960</CHIP> in this case.
Once removed, check  <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>; before soldering new one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: i was changed <CHIP>U6960</CHIP>(twice) but now ppbus is 1v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
"Once removed, check  <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>; before soldering new one."
?

You've did something wrong to kill <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode on it now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
I was talking about voltage; is the enable signal for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>.
If no present, problem may not be <CHIP>U6960</CHIP>.

Now, try to get back correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.message:

how to i get back the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
Check first diode mode to ground on it.
Next, check <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
If all present, machine should be detected in DFU.
Also check G3S and SSD voltages.

cant enter DFU

threads.message:
Possibly damaged T2.
Any liquid sign on the audio board/flex?

<CHIP>U6500</CHIP> area was with water damage..
<SIGNAL>PP5V_3GS</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
Did you follow all the steps in DFU tutorial?
If you can't enter DFU, there is a problem with T2, its communication with <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, or USB-C lines.
Supposing all AWAKE and SLPS2R (T2 power lines) voltages are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: o.k, i was lift <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and under both of the was corrosion! so i was clean and replaced(from donor board) now i get 20v but A puls from 0.03-0.00 and with battery is 20v a0.3-a0.0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: Still can't enter DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message: Still can’t..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage 5v
threads.message:
Inspect USB-C terminals for corrosion.
Check diode mode to ground on their data lines also.
